Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of a Direct Detection Energy Loss Spectroscopy System
Award.AbstractNarration:
MRI: Development of a Direct Detection Energy Loss Spectroscopy System

Nontechnical: Characterizing dynamic processes and reactions---how atoms move--is necessary to tackle key scientific issues in energy, medicine, and nanotechnology. To address this need, a multidisciplinary team of researchers are developing a new ultrafast spectroscopy system based on direct-detection technology. This state-of-the-art system enables dynamic studies of electronic and structural behavior in a wide range of materials and represents the first time in situ electron energy loss spectroscopy is being introduced to the electron microscopy marketplace, thus creating far-reaching and interdisciplinary impacts in the field of electron microscopy. Drexel's central location among many of the nation's top institutions ensures exposure to myriad universities, laboratories, and users. The development team boasts various collaborations (both in the US and internationally), which gives the new system automatic visibility. Opportunities for education and outreach include leveraging the NSF-funded Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program to recruit minority students to train and be educated within the context of electron microscopy and to take advantage of Drexel's renowned co-operative engineering education program.

Technical: Energy loss spectroscopy is particularly useful to probe electronic states, band structure, and chemistry, and to improve contrast in materials. While significant advancements in electron optics have permitted fine probe analysis of structure and chemical bonding at the atomic level, the next frontier in transmission electron microscopy (TEM) relies on imaging dynamic processes and reactions beyond standard video frame rates. Key developments in post column energy filters and direct detection cameras have enabled experiments at fine temporal and spatial scales; while these developments have advanced research individually, it is clear that the combination of direct detection technology with energy filtered imaging and spectroscopy would have substantial benefits. To date, these techniques have not been combined due to the inherent mismatch between the low-dose requirements of the direct detection applications and the very high dynamic range of electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS). This instrument development activity integrates a direct detection camera system and a high resolution spectrometer to allow for in situ EELS to be performed at low electron doses and high speeds. This unprecedented combination boosts the analytical sensitivity of inelastic scattering techniques and yields compositional and electronic structure mapping at sub-nanometer to atomic spatial scales, and high-speed (4000 frames per second) detection at low energies, permitting quantitative time-resolved data acquisition for rapid processes. The combination of expertise of energy filtering systems and energy loss spectroscopy with expertise in in situ and ultrafast TEM provides insight into key processes and bridges gaps in the understanding of mechanisms in various disciplines, with direct and specific impacts on (1) charge mediated properties in oxide and semiconductor heterostructures (2) ion transfer in energy storage materials, and (3) assembly mechanisms in biomedical and soft materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview.

The purpose of this NSF MRI was to develop a new detector for electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) using direct detection (DD) technology and electron counting. EELS is a powerful materials characterization technique that offers nanoscale information on materials? elemental composition, chemical bonding, dielectric function, band gap, and phonon modes. However, this technique has drawbacks, namely, poor signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and poor combined energy resolution and energy field of view. These drawbacks lead to fundament limitations for a wide range of EELS experiments, particularly for the characterization of electron beam sensitive samples, e.g. soft matter, and for in situ time-resolved studies of chemical and physical reactions. Electron counting with DD is a new technology for electron detection which significantly increases SNR and resolution, and this technology has shown great success for imaging within the electron microscope. To date, DD has not been applied to EELS. Thus our aim was to bring DD technology to the field of EELS, and then to use this new technique to perform previously impractical (or impossible) materials science experiments.

 

Intellectual Merit.

Through this MRI, we have successfully developed a DD EELS system, and we have quantitatively shown that it offers considerable advantages. By performing a one-to-one comparison between our DD EELS system and a conventional EELS system, we demonstrated between a 2? and >10? increase in SNR performance (depending on electron dose) and up to an 8? increase in combined energy resolution and energy field of view (Figure 1). These findings are critical to the EELS experimentalist. The increase in SNR facilitates the study of beam sensitive samples too fragile to previously have been studied with EELS, and this advance also enables the study of dynamic chemical/physical reactions too fast for conventional EELS. The improved energy resolution and energy field of view will allow both a material?s elemental composition and its chemical bonding to be studied at once; such analysis was not practical with conventional EELS.

 

Having demonstrated the superior performance of the DD EELS system developed through this MRI, we next applied this technology to important materials science problems requiring the benefits of DD EELS. To understand a new method of polymer nanoparticle self-assembly, namely, functionalization induced self-assembly, we performed extremely low-dose elemental mapping with DD EELS. These EELS experiments were critical in demonstrating the new polymer synthesis method (with applications in drug delivery), and this work could not have been performed with conventional EELS (Figure 2). We also applied DD EELS to a growing family of 2D materials named MXenes, which show excellent promise for applications including energy storage, wireless communication, and catalysis. Through time-resolved DD EELS measurements with in situ annealing and electric biasing, we were able to uncover fundamental relationships between the MXene surface chemistry and electronic properties. In this work we show how to tailor the MXene surface termination and intercalation to increase electronic conductivity and thereby increase performance in applications such as energy storage. Additional work that was conducted with DD EELS include: development of extended-edge fine structure analysis at high energies (>5 keV), oxidation state mapping in oxide heterostructures for next generation memory applications, and trace element analysis in electrocatalytic nanostructures.  

 

Broader Impact.  Technologically, the results of this proposal have far reaching implications for all scientific fields which require nanoscale materials characterization, particularly for materials which are sensitive to the electron beam like biological matter, catalytic nanoparticles, etc. While the first DD EELS system was developed at Drexel, many other research groups have ordered the product developed in this MRI from Gatan Inc, demonstrating the excitement and advanced capabilities offered by DD EELS. Educationally, the PI championed participation of minority and female students in STEM fields through the Drexel WINS (Women in Nuclear Science) program, at the K-12 level through ASM Materials Camp, Philly Materials Day, and a partnership with the Science Leadership Academy-Beeber. Also, this project resulted in an in situ Microscopy workshop held at Drexel, which highlighted the DD EELS system. This project funded the PhD research of James Hart and funded ? of the work of another PhD student, Andrew Lang.
